item.title: About
item.description:
One is a minimal blog theme for Hugo, which is forked from onetwothree.

Source code is released under the MIT license on GitHub. Feel free to use if you want to learn more or contribute.

item.title: Farr, M.T., Green, D.S., Holekamp, K.E., and Zipkin, E.F. (In Prep) Integrating distance sampling with presence only data.
item.description: I am developing an integrated species distribution model that combines presence only data from opportunistic surveying with distance sampling. Species distribution modeling (SDM) uses ecological covariates and occurrence data to predict a speciesâ€™ distribution. However, SDMs often return biased estimates due to imperfect detection and sampling bias, but model estimates can be improved by integrating more structured sampling into the model. I am working with David Green and the Holekamp lab to demonstrate the use of ISDMs by combining presence only data and distance sampling to evaluate human disturbance and apex predator decline on black-backed jackal distribution.

item.title: Saunders, S.P., Farr, M.T., Wright, A.D., Bahlai, C.A., Ribeiro, J.W., Rossman, S., Sussman, A.L., Arnold, T.W., & Zipkin E.F. (In Review) Disentangling data discrepancies and deficiencies with integrated population models.
item.description: The Zipkin lab is collaborating with Todd Arnold to use an integrated population model (IPM) to estimate population size and vital rates of the American woodcock (AMWO) using harvest data, band recovery data, and Singing Ground Surveys. We use an IPM framework to integrates multiple datatypes from AMWO and analyze them in conjunction. The results from our IPM reconcile discrepancies in inference from past studies that analyzed these datatypes independently.
